passage:
The relentless growth of the internet continues to produce phenomena—from email and instant messaging to social networking and real-time communications—that are transforming society. The increasingly significant field of Web science aims to discover and analyze how websites, trends, and virtual interactions and transactions occur and how they impact society positively or negatively. It involves observation of the micro interactions of people on the Web, such as instant-messaging conversations, as well as the macro effects of the internet on the world stage, such as YouTube stardom. The benefits and dangers of internet use often depend on who is using it and how.
	For example, Facebook currently has over a billion and a half profiles globally. Families and friends, hundreds or thousands of miles apart, can share news and stay connected instantly. Businesses can reach out to and interact with customers on a more personal level. Communities can increase publicity and attendance to their events, and awareness movements can spread rapidly throughout regions, states, and even countries. But even Facebook has a darker side.
	Cyberbullying is rampant through social media. Over 43 percent of children have experienced some form of cyberbullying through harassment, threats, ridicule, and intimidation. This can result in low self-esteem, fear, depression, and even suicide. Facebook and other social media sites should have intense monitoring of content to prevent posts from inciting violence, hate speech, and other illegal activity.
	Another serious problem the internet faces is cyberstalking. Cyberstalking is using email, social media, technology, and websites to stalk, follow, or obsess over a person. Sometimes it is a person from a former relationship or a mentally ill person who is delusional and believes this person is a friend. Identity theft is the most serious form of cyberstalking.
	Identity theft involves a criminal who steals the identity of a person, usually through personal information the person has shared on the internet. The criminal can then steal money, open new bank accounts, forge documents, and cause havoc in the victim’s life.
	Preventing and stopping cybercrime is very difficult. There is usually very little evidence, and sometimes a person does not know he or she is a victim. Web science studies are showing that the best way to prevent problems is to make Web pages and Web interactions more trustworthy.
	Best practices based on recent findings include visiting pages created by sources such as universities, as well as those that encourage the use of reputable services such as PayPal. Using internet security programs to protect yourself and your computer can help against spyware, viruses, and hacking. Don’t share passwords, and keep social media settings as private as possible. No one is 100 percent protected, but a few simple steps can protect people from most cybercrimes, and reporting any suspicious activity can help save other possible victims.

questions.description: Which of the following statements best supports the main point?

options.description: Social norms have the greatest impact on the Web.
The internet is too dangerous to use for any personaltransactions, and people should go back to using traditionalshopping methods.
The internet has positive and negative aspects that should beconsidered carefully when using it.
The Web was created as a tool for researchers and is the best

questions.description: The main purpose of paragraph 1 is

options.description: to describe the growth of internet use over time.
to explain the field of Web science.
to warn of the dangers of using the internet.
to illustrate how people are being spied on by scientists.

questions.description: All of the following statements are benefits of using social media except

options.description: staying connected to friends and families.
having more interaction with customers.
increasing public awareness of events.
sharing private videos and photos with strangers.

questions.description: In paragraph 3, the word rampant most likely means

options.description: “vicious.”
“ubiquitous.”
“contagious.”
“exclusive.”

questions.description: The author would most likely agree with which of the following statements about paragraph 3?

options.description: Facebook is at fault for allowing cyberbullying to occur.
Children who are cyberbullied should stay off social media if itmakes them feel bad.
Social media companies should monitor their sites more closelyfor cyberbullying and take a stand against it.
Parents should sue social media sites if their children are victims

questions.description: In paragraph 3, the word inciting most nearly means

options.description: “disseminating.”
“condemning.”
“provoking.”
“celebrating.”

questions.description: All of the following statements are reasons cybercrime is difficult to prevent except

options.description: there is very little evidence a crime occurred.
a person might not recognize being a victim.
it is easy to tamper with computer evidence.
people do not take the right security precautions.

questions.description: Someone who commits identity theft might

options.description: try to move into the victim’s house.
open credit cards in the victim’s name.
steal another person’s job.
fake his or her own death.

questions.description: In paragraph 4, the word havoc most likely means

options.description: “chaos.”
“attrition.”
“vengeance.”
“remorse.”

questions.description: According to the graph, which of the following statements is most likely true?

options.description: Cyberbullying has increased 2000 percent in less than a decade.
Bullying only became a serious problem when people startedusing social media.
The graph is not useful because it doesn’t specify which socialmedia site is being used.
Bullying is the most widespread cybercrime happening in 2013.

questions.description: The graph implies I.   more instances of cyberbullying are being reported. II.   people are bigger bullies in 2013 than in 2007. III.   advancing technology makes bullying easier.

options.description: I
I and II
II and III
I and III

questions.description: We can infer from the conclusion that

options.description: cybercrime cannot be stopped.
cyberbullying is the most serious cybercrime.
people can take actions to protect themselves from cybercrime.
it is the responsibility of social media sites to protect users.
